moves.1. e4: Gotta love king pawn opening, it opens up two positional promotion routes for the queen and bishop.
moves.2. Nf3: Maintaining the tempo, and making the opponent respond to my move
moves.3. d4: Queen pawn follow up allows for the removal of the e5 pawn, via a pawn for pawn trade
moves.3... Bd6: Bishop maintains the tension in the middle four squares
moves.4. Nc3: Classic attack, the knight allows for a wide variation of attacks
moves.4... c5: Black is directly challenging the centre four squares but is at a disadvantage, the pawns only attack the black squares and there are limited follow on options with blacks setup
moves.5. dxc5: Pawn takes pawn to attack the bishop with both the pawn and the queen.
moves.5... Bxc5: Bishop makes only obvious move. Opens black up to a structural weakness as no pawns can threaten d5
moves.6. Nd5: Knight promotion to d5 results in a long term structural problem for black.
moves.6... Qa5+: A wasted move, that allows for the promotion of my bishop to directly threaten the queen, causing a temporal advantage
moves.7... Qa4: This move surprised me. As a result the d5 knight has a choice, push forward for the fork or withdraw to c3 to threaten the queen and protect the e4 pawn and king.
moves.8. Nc3: DEFENCE DEFENCE DEFENCE... Structural defence to protect my centre and left side (a side)
moves.8... Qc6: Queen withdraws, maintaining attack on e4, but with the pawn on e6 this is a non event threat, if black's next move was pawn to f5 it would change the tempo of the game. It would cause the re-direction of effort from aiming at the A side to aiming at the more vulnerable H side, kings weak side.
moves.9. Bd3: Bishop promotion combines the queen thru to bishop synergies. Allows for king side castle and protect f2 with the king and rook.
moves.9... b5: I don't see the point of this move.... It doesn't allow for new lines of attack or threaten me to require a response. This in context with the ability to castle king side means minimal effect
moves.10. Nd5: Returning knight to d5, limits movement of black and reopens the c7 fork. Need to wait for pawn push to d6, this enables queen to e2. To drive a pin from b5 through the queen onto the king.
moves.10... a6: The possible pin is mitigated by the pawn to a6, bishop to b4 threatens the black c5 bishop, while being covered by the d5 knight. Three obvious moves 1- black Bishop takes the b4 bishop 2- the a pawn is moved forward to move the white bishop 3 - d pawn move to support the black bishop
moves.11... d6: Opportunity to setup the queen-king pin, promote my queen, and also protect from the attack on f2, or setup knight to get behind the h-side pawn line
moves.12. Nh4: Push knight forward to increase the complexity of the attack....
moves.12... a5: A pawn to move my bishop.... Promote queen to enable the pin, sacrifice bishop for the queen.
moves.14... Bg4: Temporal advantage, take queen then take bishop
moves.15. Bxc6+:
Bazinga!
Expected move knight takes my bishop. Then my queen will take the g4 bishop.
moves.15... Nxc6 16. Qxg4: Queen takes knight, blocks possible castle to a side. Expected move pawn f6 to f5 to attack the queen and open up the knight.
moves.16... Rd8: Block in h side, also enables the queen to attack the g7 pawn.
moves.17. Nf5 h5:
Queen to g6 or to g7
G6- check, k to d7, q to g7 check either knight to e7 or king to c8.
G7- allows for Q to press h8 then h7
